block.p: That one person can make a difference was the clarion message of the life of Rosa Parks, the seamstress who set off the seminal Montgomery, Ala., bus boycott in 1955.

It was also the clarion, if unspoken, message of President Bush's unprecedented three nominations this year for vacancies on the United States Supreme Court. The death of Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, and Justice Sandra Day O'Connor's intention to retire, opened two seats on a body in which Justice O'Connor has frequently cast a libertarian swing vote on culture-war issues like abortion and the death penalty.

It was also the clarion, if unspoken, message of President Bush's unprecedented three nominations this year for vacancies on the United States Supreme Court. The death of Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, and Justice Sandra Day O'Connor's intention to retire, opened two seats on a body in which Justice O'Connor has frequently cast a libertarian swing vote on culture-war issues like abortion and the death penalty.

Conservatives cheered the smooth confirmation of John G. Roberts Jr. as chief justice, and delivered a brusque rejection of the nomination of Harriet Miers. Whether the conservative juggernaut will hold as Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. faces hearings may depend on how President Bush recovers from the damage his approval ratings from the botched response to Hurricane Katrina and the leak investigation that threatens the White House's political genius, Karl Rove, surely one man in this administration, other than Mr. Bush himself, who really can make a difference.
